AI regulation: a pro-innovation approach

This white paper details our plans for implementing a pro-innovation approach to AI regulation. We're seeking views through a supporting consultation.

From:
Department for Science, Innovation and Technology and Office for Artificial Intelligence
Published
29 March 2023
Last updated
3 August 2023 — See all updates
This was published under the 2022 to 2024 Sunak Conservative government

Details

Annex C: correction (4 July 2023)

We have been notified of minor errors in Annex C by a stakeholder. The formal consultation period closed on 21 June, but we continue to engage with stakeholders in view of the fast-moving AI landscape. We encourage those who wish to engage with us further around the issues explored in the consultation to email us at evidence@officeforai.gov.uk.

In the National AI Strategy, the government committed to developing a pro-innovation national position on governing and regulating AI, and we outlined our position in a policy paper in 2022. This white paper sets out the government’s proposals for implementing a proportionate, future-proof and pro-innovation framework for regulating AI.

The UK Science and Technology Framework sets out the government’s strategic vision to make the UK a science and technology superpower by 2030. It identifies AI as one of five critical technologies and notes that regulation plays an important role in creating an environment for AI to flourish.

Through this new approach to AI regulation, the government will help the UK harness the opportunities and benefits that AI technologies present. This will drive growth and prosperity by boosting innovation and investment, and building public trust in AI. It will strengthen the UK’s position as a global leader in AI, by ensuring the UK is the best place to develop and use AI technologies.

Consultation

We consulted on the white paper and the related impact assessment.

The consultation closed at 11:45pm on 21 June 2023.

We are analysing your feedback.

      "@type": "Question",
      "name": "What does the Online Safety Act do?",
      "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/online-safety-act-explainer/online-safety-act-explainer#what-does-the-online-safety-act-do",
      "acceptedAnswer": {
        "@type": "Answer",
        "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/online-safety-act-explainer/online-safety-act-explainer#what-does-the-online-safety-act-do",
        "text": "\u003cfigure class=\"image embedded\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"img\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/67d445a01b26cbdf9b851dba/s960_OSA_GovUK_1.png\" alt=\"\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe Online Safety Act 2023 (the Act) is a new set of laws that protects children and adults online. It puts a range of new duties on social media companies and search services, making them more responsible for their users’ safety on their platforms. The Act will give providers new duties to implement systems and processes to reduce risks their services are used for illegal activity, and to take down illegal content when it does appear. \u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe strongest protections in the Act have been designed for children. Platforms will be required to prevent children from accessing harmful and age-inappropriate content and provide parents and children with clear and accessible ways to report problems online when they do arise. \u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe Act will also protect adult users, ensuring that major platforms will need to be more transparent about which kinds of potentially harmful content they allow, and give people more control over the types of content they want to see. \u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e is the independent regulator of Online Safety. It will set out steps providers can take to fulfil their safety duties in codes of practice. It has a broad range of powers to assess and enforce providers’ compliance with the framework. \u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eProviders’ safety duties are proportionate to factors including the risk of harm to individuals, and the size and capacity of each provider. This makes sure that while safety measures will need to be put in place across the board, we aren’t requiring small services with limited functionality to take the same actions as the largest corporations. \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e is required to take users’ rights into account when setting out steps to take. And providers have simultaneous duties to pay particular regard to users’ rights when fulfilling their safety duties.\u003c/p\u003e"
      }
    },
    {
      "@type": "Question",
      "name": "Who the Act applies to ",
      "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/online-safety-act-explainer/online-safety-act-explainer#who-the-act-applies-to",
      "acceptedAnswer": {
        "@type": "Answer",
        "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/online-safety-act-explainer/online-safety-act-explainer#who-the-act-applies-to",
        "text": "\u003cp\u003eThe Act’s duties apply to search services and services that allow users to post content online or to interact with each other. This includes a range of websites, apps and other services, including social media services, consumer file cloud storage and sharing sites, video-sharing platforms, online forums, dating services, and online instant messaging services. \u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe Act applies to services even if the companies providing them are outside the UK should they have links to the UK. This includes if the service has a significant number of UK users, if the UK is a target market, or it is capable of being accessed by UK users and there is a material risk of significant harm to such users.\u003c/p\u003e"
      }
    },
    {
      "@type": "Question",
      "name": "How the Online Safety Act is being implemented",
      "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/online-safety-act-explainer/online-safety-act-explainer#how-the-online-safety-act-is-being-implemented",
      "acceptedAnswer": {
        "@type": "Answer",
        "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/online-safety-act-explainer/online-safety-act-explainer#how-the-online-safety-act-is-being-implemented",
        "text": "\u003cfigure class=\"image embedded\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"img\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/67d4467a4bcf261f8233f805/s960_OSA_GovUK_3.png\" alt=\"\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe Act passed into law on 26 October 2023. Now work is being carried out to bring its protections into effect as quickly as possible. \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e published an updated roadmap setting out its implementation plans on 17 October 2024. \u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e is leading work to implement the Act’s provisions and are taking a phased approach to bringing duties into effect. The government also needs to make secondary legislation in some areas to enable elements of the framework. \u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe Act requires \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e to develop guidance and codes of practice that will set out how online platforms can meet their duties. \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e must carry out public consultations on draft codes of practice before finalising them, and the codes must be laid before Parliament before they take effect. The main phases are set out below:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDuties about illegal content\u003c/strong\u003e – the illegal content duties are now in effect, and as of 17 March \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e can now enforce against the regime. In-scope service providers must have now completed their assessments of the risk of illegal content appearing on their service; the deadline to do so was 16 March. The illegal harms codes of practice were approved by Parliament after being laid on 16 December 2024. On the same day in December, \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e published its illegal content risk assessment guidance and its policy statement about protecting people from illegal harms online.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDuties about content harmful to children\u003c/strong\u003e – \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e published its guidance about use of age assurance to prevent children accessing online pornography in January 2025. Platforms that publish their own pornographic content (known as Part 5 services) must take steps immediately to introduce robust age checks that meet \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e’s guidance. The corresponding duty in the Act (section 81) came into force on 17 January 2025. \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e also published its children’s access assessment guidance in January. In-scope service providers had until 16 April to carry out a children’s access assessment, to determine if their service is likely to be accessed by children.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eOn 24 April 2025, the protection of children codes of practice were laid in Parliament and \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e published guidance on how providers should carry out risk assessments for assessing the risk of harm to children. Services likely to be accessed by children, now have 3 months with a deadline of 24 July 2025, to complete their children’s risk assessment. The child safety regime will be fully in effect by Summer 2025.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDuties for categorised services\u003c/strong\u003e – some platforms will have to comply with additional requirements to enhance transparency and accountability. The Act created categories of service and thresholds for each category (Category 1, 2A and 2B) were laid via secondary legislation on 16 December 2024.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eOnce the regulations to set the thresholds have been laid and approved by Parliament, \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e will publish a register setting out which services fall into which categories and will publish further codes of practice for consultation. \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e expects to publish the register of categorised services in Summer 2025 and consult on the codes of practice and, where relevant, guidance for the additional duties on categorised services by early 2026.\u003c/p\u003e"
      }
    },
    {
      "@type": "Question",
      "name": "The new offences that the Act has introduced",
      "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/online-safety-act-explainer/online-safety-act-explainer#the-new-offences-that-the-act-has-introduced",
      "acceptedAnswer": {
        "@type": "Answer",
        "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/online-safety-act-explainer/online-safety-act-explainer#the-new-offences-that-the-act-has-introduced",
        "text": "\u003cfigure class=\"image embedded\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"img\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/67d446caa4075fa7b9851dd2/s960_OSA_GovUK_4.png\" alt=\"\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe criminal offences introduced by the Act came into effect on 31 January 2024. These offences cover: \u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eencouraging or assisting serious self-harm\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003ecyberflashing\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003esending false information intended to cause non-trivial harm\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003ethreatening communications\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eintimate image abuse\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eepilepsy trolling\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003eThese new offences apply directly to the individuals sending them, and convictions have already been made under the cyberflashing and threatening communications offences. \u003c/p\u003e"
      }
    },
    {
      "@type": "Question",
      "name": "Types of content the Act tackles",
      "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/online-safety-act-explainer/online-safety-act-explainer#types-of-content-the-act-tackles",
      "acceptedAnswer": {
        "@type": "Answer",
        "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/online-safety-act-explainer/online-safety-act-explainer#types-of-content-the-act-tackles",
        "text": "\u003cfigure class=\"image embedded\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"img\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/67d4471f6ec9d5faee33f807/s960_OSA_GovUK_5.png\" alt=\"\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\u003ch3 id=\"illegal-content\"\u003eIllegal content\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe Act requires all companies to take robust action against illegal content and activity. Platforms are now required to implement measures to reduce the risks their services are used for illegal offending. They also need to put in place systems for removing illegal content when it does appear. Search services also have new duties to take steps to reduce the risks users encounter illegal content via their services.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe Act sets out a list of priority offences. These reflect the most serious and prevalent illegal content and activity, against which companies must take proactive measures.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003ePlatforms must also remove any other illegal content where there is an individual victim (actual or intended), where it is flagged to them by users, or where they become aware of it through any other means.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe illegal content duties are not just about removing existing illegal content; they are also about stopping it from appearing at all. Platforms need to think about how they design their sites to reduce the likelihood of them being used for criminal activity in the first place.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe kinds of illegal content and activity that platforms need to protect users from are set out in the Act, and this includes content relating to:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003echild sexual abuse  \u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003econtrolling or coercive behaviour  \u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eextreme sexual violence \u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eextreme pornography \u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003efraud\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eracially or religiously aggravated public order offences  \u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003einciting violence  \u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eillegal immigration and people smuggling  \u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003epromoting or facilitating suicide  \u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eintimate image abuse\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eselling illegal drugs or weapons  \u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003esexual exploitation  \u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eterrorism \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3 id=\"content-that-is-harmful-to-children\"\u003eContent that is harmful to children \u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eProtecting children is at the heart of the Online Safety Act. Although some content is not illegal, it could be harmful or age-inappropriate for children and platforms need to protect children from it. \u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCompanies with websites in-scope of the Act that are likely to be accessed by children need to take steps to protect children from harmful content and behaviour.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe categories of harmful content that platforms need to protect children from encountering are set out in the Act. Children must be prevented from accessing Primary Priority Content, and should be given age-appropriate access to Priority Content. The types of content which fall into these categories are set out below.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch4 id=\"primary-priority-content\"\u003ePrimary Priority Content\u003c/h4\u003e\u003cul\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003epornography\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003econtent that encourages, promotes, or provides instructions for either:\n    \u003cul\u003e\n      \u003cli\u003eself-harm\u003c/li\u003e\n      \u003cli\u003eeating disorders or\u003c/li\u003e\n      \u003cli\u003esuicide\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003c/ul\u003e\n  \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch4 id=\"priority-content\"\u003ePriority Content\u003c/h4\u003e\u003cul\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003ebullying\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eabusive or hateful content\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003econtent which depicts or encourages serious violence or injury\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003econtent which encourages dangerous stunts and challenges; and\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003econtent which encourages the ingestion, inhalation or exposure to harmful substances.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e"
      }

      "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/online-safety-act-explainer/online-safety-act-explainer#adults-will-have-more-control-over-the-content-they-see",
      "acceptedAnswer": {

        "text": "\u003cfigure class=\"image embedded\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"img\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/67d447924047b1c7801b5c01/s960_OSA_GovUK_7.png\" alt=\"\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\u003cp\u003eLarge user-to-user services, known as Category 1 services, will be required to offer adult users tools which, if they choose to use, will give them greater control over the kinds of content they see and who they engage with online.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAdult users of such services will be able to verify their identity and access tools which enable them to reduce the likelihood that they see content from non-verified users and prevent non-verified users from interacting with their content. This will help stop anonymous trolls from contacting them.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFollowing the publication of guidance by \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e, Category 1 services  will also need to proactively offer adult users optional tools, at the first opportunity, to help them reduce the likelihood that they will encounter certain types of legal content. These categories of content are set out in the Act and include content that does not meet a criminal threshold but encourages, promotes or provides instructions for suicide, self-harm or eating disorders. These tools also apply to abusive or hate content including where such content is racist, antisemitic, homophobic, or misogynist. The tools must be effective and easy to access.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe Act already protects children from seeing this content.\u003c/p\u003e"

      "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/online-safety-act-explainer/online-safety-act-explainer#the-act-will-tackle-suicide-and-self-harm-content",
      "acceptedAnswer": {
        "@type": "Answer",
        "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/online-safety-act-explainer/online-safety-act-explainer#the-act-will-tackle-suicide-and-self-harm-content",
        "text": "\u003cp\u003eAny site that allows users to share content or interact with each other is in scope of the Online Safety Act. These laws also require sites to rapidly remove illegal suicide and self-harm content and proactively protect users from content that is illegal under the Suicide Act 1961. The Act has also introduced a new criminal offence for intentionally encouraging or assisting serious self-harm.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eServices that are likely to be accessed by children must prevent children of all ages from encountering legal content that encourages, promotes or provides instruction for suicide and self-harm. \u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFollowing a letter from the Secretary of State, in September 2024, \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e set out their approach to regulating small but risky platforms. \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e have established a dedicated small but risky supervision taskforce to monitor such services, and move to rapid enforcement where there is evidence of non-compliance with their duties to tackle illegal content and, where relevant, content that is harmful to children.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe Act also requires large services (Category 1 services) to uphold their terms of service where they say they will remove or restrict content or suspend users. If a service says they prohibit certain kinds of legal suicide or self-harm content the Act requires them to enforce these terms consistently and transparently. These companies must also have effective reporting and redress mechanisms in place enabling users to raise concerns about companies’ enforcement of their terms of service, if users feel that companies are not fulfilling their duties.\u003c/p\u003e"
      }

      "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/online-safety-act-explainer/online-safety-act-explainer#how-the-act-will-be-enforced",
      "acceptedAnswer": {

        "text": "\u003cfigure class=\"image embedded\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"img\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/67d447b94047b1c7801b5c02/s960_OSA_GovUK_8.png\" alt=\"\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e is now the regulator of online safety and must make sure that platforms are protecting their users. Once the new duties are in effect, following \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e’s publication of final codes and guidance, platforms will have to show they have processes in place to meet the requirements set out by the Act. \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e will monitor how effective those processes are at protecting internet users from harm. \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e will have powers to take action against companies which do not follow their new duties.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCompanies can be fined up to £18 million or 10 percent of their qualifying worldwide revenue, whichever is greater. Criminal action can be taken against senior managers who fail to ensure companies follow information requests from \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e. \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e will also be able to hold companies and senior managers (where they are at fault) criminally liable if the provider fails to comply with \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e’s enforcement notices in relation to specific child safety duties or to for child sexual abuse and exploitation on their service.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn the most extreme cases, with the agreement of the courts, \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e will be able to require payment providers, advertisers and internet service providers to stop working with a site, preventing it from generating money or being accessed from the UK.\u003c/p\u003e"

This includes considering their platform’s design, functionalities, algorithms, and any other features likely to meet the illegal content and child safety duties.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe law also makes it clear that harm can arise from the way content is disseminated, such as when an algorithm repeatedly pushes content to a child in large volumes over a short space of time.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCategorised services will be required to publish annual transparency reports containing online safety related information, such as information about the algorithms they use and their effect on users’ experience, including children.\u003c/p\u003e"

        "text": "\u003cfigure class=\"image embedded\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"img\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/67d448144bcf261f8233f810/s960_OSA_GovUK_10.png\" alt=\"\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\u003cp\u003eMuch of the most harmful illegal online content disproportionately affects women and girls, and the Act requires platforms to proactively tackle this. Illegal content includes harassment, stalking, controlling or coercive behaviour, extreme pornography, and intimate image abuse.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAll user-to-user and search services have duties to put in place systems and processes to remove this content when it is flagged to them. The measures companies must take to remove illegal content will be set out in \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e’s codes of practice.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhen developing these codes, \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e is required to consult with the Victim’s Commissioner and Domestic Abuse Commissioner to guarantee that the voices and views of women, girls and victims are reflected. \u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe Act also requires \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e to produce guidance that summarises in one clear place the measures that can be taken to tackle the abuse that women and girls disproportionately face online. This guidance will ensure it is easy for platforms to implement holistic and effective protections for women and girls across their various duties. On 25 February, \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e published their draft guidance for consultation. This guidance will be subject to a 12-week consultation with finalised guidance published by the end of the year. All companies in scope of the Act should refer to this guidance when implementing protections for users.\u003c/p\u003e"

        "text": "\u003cp\u003eThe Online Safety Act takes a proportionate approach to mis- and disinformation by focusing on addressing the greatest risks of harm to users, whilst protecting freedom of expression.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eMis- and disinformation will be captured by the Online Safety Act where it is illegal or harmful to children. Services will be required to take steps to remove illegal disinformation content if they become aware of it on their services. This includes the removal of illegal, state-sponsored disinformation through the Foreign Interference Offence, forcing companies to take action against a range of state-sponsored disinformation and state-linked interference online. This includes protections against in-scope mis- and disinformation.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eCategory 1 services will also need to remove certain types of mis- and disinformation if they are prohibited in their terms of services.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe Online Safety Act also requires \u003cabbr title=\"Office of Communications\"\u003eOfcom\u003c/abbr\u003e to establish an advisory committee on disinformation and misinformation to build cross-sector understanding of mis- and disinformation. The advisory committee has now appointed a Chair and plans to have its first meeting in April 2025.\u003c/p\u003e"

<h2 id="what-does-the-online-safety-act-do">What does the Online Safety Act do?</h2>

<figure class="image embedded"><div class="img"><img src="https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/67d445a01b26cbdf9b851dba/s960_OSA_GovUK_1.png" alt=""></div></figure>

<p>The Online Safety Act 2023 (the Act) is a new set of laws that protects children and adults online. It puts a range of new duties on social media companies and search services, making them more responsible for their users’ safety on their platforms. The Act will give providers new duties to implement systems and processes to reduce risks their services are used for illegal activity, and to take down illegal content when it does appear. </p>

<p>The strongest protections in the Act have been designed for children. Platforms will be required to prevent children from accessing harmful and age-inappropriate content and provide parents and children with clear and accessible ways to report problems online when they do arise. </p>

<p>The Act will also protect adult users, ensuring that major platforms will need to be more transparent about which kinds of potentially harmful content they allow, and give people more control over the types of content they want to see. </p>

<p><abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> is the independent regulator of Online Safety. It will set out steps providers can take to fulfil their safety duties in codes of practice. It has a broad range of powers to assess and enforce providers’ compliance with the framework. </p>

<p>Providers’ safety duties are proportionate to factors including the risk of harm to individuals, and the size and capacity of each provider. This makes sure that while safety measures will need to be put in place across the board, we aren’t requiring small services with limited functionality to take the same actions as the largest corporations. <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> is required to take users’ rights into account when setting out steps to take. And providers have simultaneous duties to pay particular regard to users’ rights when fulfilling their safety duties.</p>

<h2 id="who-the-act-applies-to">Who the Act applies to </h2>

<p>The Act’s duties apply to search services and services that allow users to post content online or to interact with each other. This includes a range of websites, apps and other services, including social media services, consumer file cloud storage and sharing sites, video-sharing platforms, online forums, dating services, and online instant messaging services. </p>

<p>The Act applies to services even if the companies providing them are outside the UK should they have links to the UK. This includes if the service has a significant number of UK users, if the UK is a target market, or it is capable of being accessed by UK users and there is a material risk of significant harm to such users.</p>

<h2 id="how-the-online-safety-act-is-being-implemented">How the Online Safety Act is being implemented</h2>

<figure class="image embedded"><div class="img"><img src="https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/67d4467a4bcf261f8233f805/s960_OSA_GovUK_3.png" alt=""></div></figure>

<p>The Act passed into law on 26 October 2023. Now work is being carried out to bring its protections into effect as quickly as possible. <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> published an updated roadmap setting out its implementation plans on 17 October 2024. </p>

<p><abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> is leading work to implement the Act’s provisions and are taking a phased approach to bringing duties into effect. The government also needs to make secondary legislation in some areas to enable elements of the framework. </p>

<p>The Act requires <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> to develop guidance and codes of practice that will set out how online platforms can meet their duties. <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> must carry out public consultations on draft codes of practice before finalising them, and the codes must be laid before Parliament before they take effect. The main phases are set out below:</p>

<p><strong>Duties about illegal content</strong> – the illegal content duties are now in effect, and as of 17 March <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> can now enforce against the regime. In-scope service providers must have now completed their assessments of the risk of illegal content appearing on their service; the deadline to do so was 16 March. The illegal harms codes of practice were approved by Parliament after being laid on 16 December 2024. On the same day in December, <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> published its illegal content risk assessment guidance and its policy statement about protecting people from illegal harms online.</p>

<p><strong>Duties about content harmful to children</strong> – <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> published its guidance about use of age assurance to prevent children accessing online pornography in January 2025. Platforms that publish their own pornographic content (known as Part 5 services) must take steps immediately to introduce robust age checks that meet <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr>’s guidance. The corresponding duty in the Act (section 81) came into force on 17 January 2025. <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> also published its children’s access assessment guidance in January. In-scope service providers had until 16 April to carry out a children’s access assessment, to determine if their service is likely to be accessed by children.</p>

<p>On 24 April 2025, the protection of children codes of practice were laid in Parliament and <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> published guidance on how providers should carry out risk assessments for assessing the risk of harm to children. Services likely to be accessed by children, now have 3 months with a deadline of 24 July 2025, to complete their children’s risk assessment. The child safety regime will be fully in effect by Summer 2025.</p>

<p><strong>Duties for categorised services</strong> – some platforms will have to comply with additional requirements to enhance transparency and accountability. The Act created categories of service and thresholds for each category (Category 1, 2A and 2B) were laid via secondary legislation on 16 December 2024.</p>

<p>Once the regulations to set the thresholds have been laid and approved by Parliament, <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> will publish a register setting out which services fall into which categories and will publish further codes of practice for consultation. <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> expects to publish the register of categorised services in Summer 2025 and consult on the codes of practice and, where relevant, guidance for the additional duties on categorised services by early 2026.</p>

<h2 id="the-new-offences-that-the-act-has-introduced">The new offences that the Act has introduced</h2>

<figure class="image embedded"><div class="img"><img src="https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/67d446caa4075fa7b9851dd2/s960_OSA_GovUK_4.png" alt=""></div></figure>

<p>The criminal offences introduced by the Act came into effect on 31 January 2024. These offences cover: </p>

<ul>
  <li>encouraging or assisting serious self-harm</li>
  <li>cyberflashing</li>
  <li>sending false information intended to cause non-trivial harm</li>
  <li>threatening communications</li>
  <li>intimate image abuse</li>
  <li>epilepsy trolling</li>
</ul>

<p>These new offences apply directly to the individuals sending them, and convictions have already been made under the cyberflashing and threatening communications offences. </p>

<h2 id="types-of-content-the-act-tackles">Types of content the Act tackles</h2>

<figure class="image embedded"><div class="img"><img src="https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/67d4471f6ec9d5faee33f807/s960_OSA_GovUK_5.png" alt=""></div></figure>

<h3 id="illegal-content">Illegal content</h3>

<p>The Act requires all companies to take robust action against illegal content and activity. Platforms are now required to implement measures to reduce the risks their services are used for illegal offending. They also need to put in place systems for removing illegal content when it does appear. Search services also have new duties to take steps to reduce the risks users encounter illegal content via their services.</p>

<p>The Act sets out a list of priority offences. These reflect the most serious and prevalent illegal content and activity, against which companies must take proactive measures.</p>

<p>Platforms must also remove any other illegal content where there is an individual victim (actual or intended), where it is flagged to them by users, or where they become aware of it through any other means.</p>

<p>The illegal content duties are not just about removing existing illegal content; they are also about stopping it from appearing at all. Platforms need to think about how they design their sites to reduce the likelihood of them being used for criminal activity in the first place.</p>

<p>The kinds of illegal content and activity that platforms need to protect users from are set out in the Act, and this includes content relating to:</p>

<ul>
  <li>child sexual abuse  </li>
  <li>controlling or coercive behaviour  </li>
  <li>extreme sexual violence </li>
  <li>extreme pornography </li>
  <li>fraud</li>
  <li>racially or religiously aggravated public order offences  </li>
  <li>inciting violence  </li>
  <li>illegal immigration and people smuggling  </li>
  <li>promoting or facilitating suicide  </li>
  <li>intimate image abuse</li>
  <li>selling illegal drugs or weapons  </li>
  <li>sexual exploitation  </li>
  <li>terrorism </li>
</ul>

<h3 id="content-that-is-harmful-to-children">Content that is harmful to children </h3>

<p>Protecting children is at the heart of the Online Safety Act. Although some content is not illegal, it could be harmful or age-inappropriate for children and platforms need to protect children from it. </p>

<p>Companies with websites in-scope of the Act that are likely to be accessed by children need to take steps to protect children from harmful content and behaviour.</p>

<p>The categories of harmful content that platforms need to protect children from encountering are set out in the Act. Children must be prevented from accessing Primary Priority Content, and should be given age-appropriate access to Priority Content. The types of content which fall into these categories are set out below.</p>

<h4 id="primary-priority-content">Primary Priority Content</h4>

<ul>
  <li>pornography</li>
  <li>content that encourages, promotes, or provides instructions for either:
    <ul>
      <li>self-harm</li>
      <li>eating disorders or</li>
      <li>suicide</li>
    </ul>
  </li>
</ul>

<h4 id="priority-content">Priority Content</h4>

<ul>
  <li>bullying</li>
  <li>abusive or hateful content</li>
  <li>content which depicts or encourages serious violence or injury</li>
  <li>content which encourages dangerous stunts and challenges; and</li>
  <li>content which encourages the ingestion, inhalation or exposure to harmful substances.</li>
</ul>

<h2 id="age-appropriate-experiences-for-children-online">Age-appropriate experiences for children online</h2>

<figure class="image embedded"><div class="img"><img src="https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/67d447501b26cbdf9b851dc0/s960_OSA_GovUK_6.png" alt=""></div></figure>

<p>The Act requires social media companies to enforce their age limits consistently and protect their child users.</p>

<p>Services must assess any risks to children from using their platforms and set appropriate age restrictions, ensuring that child users have age-appropriate experiences and are shielded from harmful content. Service providers who use measures to prevent access to their service for children under a certain age must specify in their terms of service, what measures are being used to enforce this age limit and enforce this consistently.</p>

<h2 id="adults-will-have-more-control-over-the-content-they-see">Adults will have more control over the content they see</h2>

<figure class="image embedded"><div class="img"><img src="https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/67d447924047b1c7801b5c01/s960_OSA_GovUK_7.png" alt=""></div></figure>

<p>Large user-to-user services, known as Category 1 services, will be required to offer adult users tools which, if they choose to use, will give them greater control over the kinds of content they see and who they engage with online.</p>

<p>Adult users of such services will be able to verify their identity and access tools which enable them to reduce the likelihood that they see content from non-verified users and prevent non-verified users from interacting with their content. This will help stop anonymous trolls from contacting them.</p>

<p>Following the publication of guidance by <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr>, Category 1 services  will also need to proactively offer adult users optional tools, at the first opportunity, to help them reduce the likelihood that they will encounter certain types of legal content. These categories of content are set out in the Act and include content that does not meet a criminal threshold but encourages, promotes or provides instructions for suicide, self-harm or eating disorders. These tools also apply to abusive or hate content including where such content is racist, antisemitic, homophobic, or misogynist. The tools must be effective and easy to access.</p>

<p>The Act already protects children from seeing this content.</p>

<h2 id="the-act-will-tackle-suicide-and-self-harm-content">The Act will tackle suicide and self-harm content </h2>

<p>Any site that allows users to share content or interact with each other is in scope of the Online Safety Act. These laws also require sites to rapidly remove illegal suicide and self-harm content and proactively protect users from content that is illegal under the Suicide Act 1961. The Act has also introduced a new criminal offence for intentionally encouraging or assisting serious self-harm.</p>

<p>Services that are likely to be accessed by children must prevent children of all ages from encountering legal content that encourages, promotes or provides instruction for suicide and self-harm. </p>

<p>Following a letter from the Secretary of State, in September 2024, <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> set out their approach to regulating small but risky platforms. <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> have established a dedicated small but risky supervision taskforce to monitor such services, and move to rapid enforcement where there is evidence of non-compliance with their duties to tackle illegal content and, where relevant, content that is harmful to children.</p>

<p>The Act also requires large services (Category 1 services) to uphold their terms of service where they say they will remove or restrict content or suspend users. If a service says they prohibit certain kinds of legal suicide or self-harm content the Act requires them to enforce these terms consistently and transparently. These companies must also have effective reporting and redress mechanisms in place enabling users to raise concerns about companies’ enforcement of their terms of service, if users feel that companies are not fulfilling their duties.</p>

<h2 id="how-the-act-will-be-enforced">How the Act will be enforced</h2>

<figure class="image embedded"><div class="img"><img src="https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/67d447b94047b1c7801b5c02/s960_OSA_GovUK_8.png" alt=""></div></figure>

<p><abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> is now the regulator of online safety and must make sure that platforms are protecting their users. Once the new duties are in effect, following <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr>’s publication of final codes and guidance, platforms will have to show they have processes in place to meet the requirements set out by the Act. <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> will monitor how effective those processes are at protecting internet users from harm. <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> will have powers to take action against companies which do not follow their new duties.</p>

<p>Companies can be fined up to £18 million or 10 percent of their qualifying worldwide revenue, whichever is greater. Criminal action can be taken against senior managers who fail to ensure companies follow information requests from <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr>. <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> will also be able to hold companies and senior managers (where they are at fault) criminally liable if the provider fails to comply with <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr>’s enforcement notices in relation to specific child safety duties or to for child sexual abuse and exploitation on their service.</p>

<p>In the most extreme cases, with the agreement of the courts, <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> will be able to require payment providers, advertisers and internet service providers to stop working with a site, preventing it from generating money or being accessed from the UK.</p>

<h2 id="how-the-act-affects-companies-that-are-not-based-in-the-uk">How the Act affects companies that are not based in the UK </h2>

<p>The Act gives <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> the powers they need to take appropriate action against all companies in scope, no matter where they are based, where services have relevant links with the UK. This means services with a significant number of UK users or where UK users are a target market, as well as other services which have in-scope content that presents a risk of significant harm to people in the UK.</p>

<h2 id="how-the-act-will-tackle-harmful-algorithms">How the Act will tackle harmful algorithms</h2>

<figure class="image embedded"><div class="img"><img src="https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/67d447dba4075fa7b9851ddb/s960_OSA_GovUK_9.png" alt=""></div></figure>

<p>The Act requires providers to specifically consider how algorithms could impact users’ exposure to illegal content – and children’s exposure content that is harmful to children – as part of their risk assessments.</p>

<p>Providers will then need to take steps to mitigate and effectively manage any identified risks. This includes considering their platform’s design, functionalities, algorithms, and any other features likely to meet the illegal content and child safety duties.</p>

<p>The law also makes it clear that harm can arise from the way content is disseminated, such as when an algorithm repeatedly pushes content to a child in large volumes over a short space of time.</p>

<p>Categorised services will be required to publish annual transparency reports containing online safety related information, such as information about the algorithms they use and their effect on users’ experience, including children.</p>

<h2 id="how-the-act-protects-women-and-girls">How the Act protects women and girls</h2>

<figure class="image embedded"><div class="img"><img src="https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/67d448144bcf261f8233f810/s960_OSA_GovUK_10.png" alt=""></div></figure>

<p>Much of the most harmful illegal online content disproportionately affects women and girls, and the Act requires platforms to proactively tackle this. Illegal content includes harassment, stalking, controlling or coercive behaviour, extreme pornography, and intimate image abuse.</p>

<p>All user-to-user and search services have duties to put in place systems and processes to remove this content when it is flagged to them. The measures companies must take to remove illegal content will be set out in <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr>’s codes of practice.</p>

<p>When developing these codes, <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> is required to consult with the Victim’s Commissioner and Domestic Abuse Commissioner to guarantee that the voices and views of women, girls and victims are reflected. </p>

<p>The Act also requires <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> to produce guidance that summarises in one clear place the measures that can be taken to tackle the abuse that women and girls disproportionately face online. This guidance will ensure it is easy for platforms to implement holistic and effective protections for women and girls across their various duties. On 25 February, <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> published their draft guidance for consultation. This guidance will be subject to a 12-week consultation with finalised guidance published by the end of the year. All companies in scope of the Act should refer to this guidance when implementing protections for users.</p>

<h2 id="how-the-act-tackles-misinformation-and-disinformation">How the Act tackles Misinformation and Disinformation    </h2>

<p>The Online Safety Act takes a proportionate approach to mis- and disinformation by focusing on addressing the greatest risks of harm to users, whilst protecting freedom of expression.</p>

<p>Mis- and disinformation will be captured by the Online Safety Act where it is illegal or harmful to children. Services will be required to take steps to remove illegal disinformation content if they become aware of it on their services. This includes the removal of illegal, state-sponsored disinformation through the Foreign Interference Offence, forcing companies to take action against a range of state-sponsored disinformation and state-linked interference online. Companies must also assess whether their service is likely to be accessed by children and, if so deliver additional protections for them. This includes protections against in-scope mis- and disinformation.</p>

<p>Category 1 services will also need to remove certain types of mis- and disinformation if they are prohibited in their terms of services.</p>

<p>The Online Safety Act also requires <abbr title="Office of Communications">Ofcom</abbr> to establish an advisory committee on disinformation and misinformation to build cross-sector understanding of mis- and disinformation. The advisory committee has now appointed a Chair and plans to have its first meeting in April 2025.</p>

<h2 id="independent-review-of-pornography-regulation-legislation-and-enforcement">Independent Review of Pornography Regulation, Legislation and Enforcement</h2>

<p>The past 2 decades have seen a dramatic change in the way we consume media and interact with content online. We need to ensure pornography regulation and legislation reflects this change.  </p>

<p>Separate to the Online Safety Act, the <a href="https://www.gov.uk/government/news/illegal-pornography-abuse-and-exploitation-to-be-investigated-by-new-reviewer">Independent Pornography Review was announced</a> to assess the regulation, legislation and enforcement of online and offline pornographic content.</p>

<p>Since December 2023, the Review was led by the Independent Lead Reviewer, Baroness Gabby Bertin.  The Independent Pornography Review’s <a href="https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/creating-a-safer-world-the-challenge-of-regulating-online-pornography">final report and its recommendations to government</a> were published on 27 February 2025. The findings of the Review continue to be assessed by the government.</p>

The Online Safety Act 2023 (the Act) is a new set of laws that protects children and adults online. It puts a range of new duties on social media companies and search services, making them more responsible for their users’ safety on their platforms. The Act will give providers new duties to implement systems and processes to reduce risks their services are used for illegal activity, and to take down illegal content when it does appear.
The strongest protections in the Act have been designed for children. Platforms will be required to prevent children from accessing harmful and age-inappropriate content and provide parents and children with clear and accessible ways to report problems online when they do arise.
The Act will also protect adult users, ensuring that major platforms will need to be more transparent about which kinds of potentially harmful content they allow, and give people more control over the types of content they want to see.
Ofcom is the independent regulator of Online Safety. It will set out steps providers can take to fulfil their safety duties in codes of practice. It has a broad range of powers to assess and enforce providers’ compliance with the framework.
Providers’ safety duties are proportionate to factors including the risk of harm to individuals, and the size and capacity of each provider. This makes sure that while safety measures will need to be put in place across the board, we aren’t requiring small services with limited functionality to take the same actions as the largest corporations. Ofcom is required to take users’ rights into account when setting out steps to take. And providers have simultaneous duties to pay particular regard to users’ rights when fulfilling their safety duties.
The Act’s duties apply to search services and services that allow users to post content online or to interact with each other. This includes a range of websites, apps and other services, including social media services, consumer file cloud storage and sharing sites, video-sharing platforms, online forums, dating services, and online instant messaging services.
The Act applies to services even if the companies providing them are outside the UK should they have links to the UK. This includes if the service has a significant number of UK users, if the UK is a target market, or it is capable of being accessed by UK users and there is a material risk of significant harm to such users.
The Act passed into law on 26 October 2023. Now work is being carried out to bring its protections into effect as quickly as possible. Ofcom published an updated roadmap setting out its implementation plans on 17 October 2024.
Ofcom is leading work to implement the Act’s provisions and are taking a phased approach to bringing duties into effect. The government also needs to make secondary legislation in some areas to enable elements of the framework.
The Act requires Ofcom to develop guidance and codes of practice that will set out how online platforms can meet their duties. Ofcom must carry out public consultations on draft codes of practice before finalising them, and the codes must be laid before Parliament before they take effect. The main phases are set out below:
Duties about illegal content – the illegal content duties are now in effect, and as of 17 March Ofcom can now enforce against the regime. In-scope service providers must have now completed their assessments of the risk of illegal content appearing on their service; the deadline to do so was 16 March. The illegal harms codes of practice were approved by Parliament after being laid on 16 December 2024. On the same day in December, Ofcom published its illegal content risk assessment guidance and its policy statement about protecting people from illegal harms online.
Duties about content harmful to children – Ofcom published its guidance about use of age assurance to prevent children accessing online pornography in January 2025. Platforms that publish their own pornographic content (known as Part 5 services) must take steps immediately to introduce robust age checks that meet Ofcom ’s guidance. The corresponding duty in the Act (section 81) came into force on 17 January 2025. Ofcom also published its children’s access assessment guidance in January. In-scope service providers had until 16 April to carry out a children’s access assessment, to determine if their service is likely to be accessed by children.
On 24 April 2025, the protection of children codes of practice were laid in Parliament and Ofcom published guidance on how providers should carry out risk assessments for assessing the risk of harm to children. Services likely to be accessed by children, now have 3 months with a deadline of 24 July 2025, to complete their children’s risk assessment. The child safety regime will be fully in effect by Summer 2025.
Duties for categorised services – some platforms will have to comply with additional requirements to enhance transparency and accountability. The Act created categories of service and thresholds for each category (Category 1, 2A and 2B) were laid via secondary legislation on 16 December 2024.
Once the regulations to set the thresholds have been laid and approved by Parliament, Ofcom will publish a register setting out which services fall into which categories and will publish further codes of practice for consultation. Ofcom expects to publish the register of categorised services in Summer 2025 and consult on the codes of practice and, where relevant, guidance for the additional duties on categorised services by early 2026.
The criminal offences introduced by the Act came into effect on 31 January 2024. These offences cover:
These new offences apply directly to the individuals sending them, and convictions have already been made under the cyberflashing and threatening communications offences.
The Act requires all companies to take robust action against illegal content and activity. Platforms are now required to implement measures to reduce the risks their services are used for illegal offending. They also need to put in place systems for removing illegal content when it does appear. Search services also have new duties to take steps to reduce the risks users encounter illegal content via their services.
The Act sets out a list of priority offences. These reflect the most serious and prevalent illegal content and activity, against which companies must take proactive measures.
Platforms must also remove any other illegal content where there is an individual victim (actual or intended), where it is flagged to them by users, or where they become aware of it through any other means.
The illegal content duties are not just about removing existing illegal content; they are also about stopping it from appearing at all. Platforms need to think about how they design their sites to reduce the likelihood of them being used for criminal activity in the first place.
The kinds of illegal content and activity that platforms need to protect users from are set out in the Act, and this includes content relating to:
Protecting children is at the heart of the Online Safety Act. Although some content is not illegal, it could be harmful or age-inappropriate for children and platforms need to protect children from it.
Companies with websites in-scope of the Act that are likely to be accessed by children need to take steps to protect children from harmful content and behaviour.
The categories of harmful content that platforms need to protect children from encountering are set out in the Act. Children must be prevented from accessing Primary Priority Content, and should be given age-appropriate access to Priority Content. The types of content which fall into these categories are set out below.
The Act requires social media companies to enforce their age limits consistently and protect their child users.
Services must assess any risks to children from using their platforms and set appropriate age restrictions, ensuring that child users have age-appropriate experiences and are shielded from harmful content. Service providers who use measures to prevent access to their service for children under a certain age must specify in their terms of service, what measures are being used to enforce this age limit and enforce this consistently.
Large user-to-user services, known as Category 1 services, will be required to offer adult users tools which, if they choose to use, will give them greater control over the kinds of content they see and who they engage with online.
Adult users of such services will be able to verify their identity and access tools which enable them to reduce the likelihood that they see content from non-verified users and prevent non-verified users from interacting with their content. This will help stop anonymous trolls from contacting them.
Following the publication of guidance by Ofcom , Category 1 services  will also need to proactively offer adult users optional tools, at the first opportunity, to help them reduce the likelihood that they will encounter certain types of legal content. These categories of content are set out in the Act and include content that does not meet a criminal threshold but encourages, promotes or provides instructions for suicide, self-harm or eating disorders. These tools also apply to abusive or hate content including where such content is racist, antisemitic, homophobic, or misogynist. The tools must be effective and easy to access.
The Act already protects children from seeing this content.
Any site that allows users to share content or interact with each other is in scope of the Online Safety Act. These laws also require sites to rapidly remove illegal suicide and self-harm content and proactively protect users from content that is illegal under the Suicide Act 1961. The Act has also introduced a new criminal offence for intentionally encouraging or assisting serious self-harm.
Services that are likely to be accessed by children must prevent children of all ages from encountering legal content that encourages, promotes or provides instruction for suicide and self-harm.
Following a letter from the Secretary of State, in September 2024, Ofcom set out their approach to regulating small but risky platforms. Ofcom have established a dedicated small but risky supervision taskforce to monitor such services, and move to rapid enforcement where there is evidence of non-compliance with their duties to tackle illegal content and, where relevant, content that is harmful to children.
The Act also requires large services (Category 1 services) to uphold their terms of service where they say they will remove or restrict content or suspend users. If a service says they prohibit certain kinds of legal suicide or self-harm content the Act requires them to enforce these terms consistently and transparently. These companies must also have effective reporting and redress mechanisms in place enabling users to raise concerns about companies’ enforcement of their terms of service, if users feel that companies are not fulfilling their duties.
Ofcom is now the regulator of online safety and must make sure that platforms are protecting their users. Once the new duties are in effect, following Ofcom ’s publication of final codes and guidance, platforms will have to show they have processes in place to meet the requirements set out by the Act. Ofcom will monitor how effective those processes are at protecting internet users from harm. Ofcom will have powers to take action against companies which do not follow their new duties.
Companies can be fined up to £18 million or 10 percent of their qualifying worldwide revenue, whichever is greater. Criminal action can be taken against senior managers who fail to ensure companies follow information requests from Ofcom . Ofcom will also be able to hold companies and senior managers (where they are at fault) criminally liable if the provider fails to comply with Ofcom ’s enforcement notices in relation to specific child safety duties or to for child sexual abuse and exploitation on their service.
In the most extreme cases, with the agreement of the courts, Ofcom will be able to require payment providers, advertisers and internet service providers to stop working with a site, preventing it from generating money or being accessed from the UK.
The Act gives Ofcom the powers they need to take appropriate action against all companies in scope, no matter where they are based, where services have relevant links with the UK. This means services with a significant number of UK users or where UK users are a target market, as well as other services which have in-scope content that presents a risk of significant harm to people in the UK.
The Act requires providers to specifically consider how algorithms could impact users’ exposure to illegal content – and children’s exposure content that is harmful to children – as part of their risk assessments.
Providers will then need to take steps to mitigate and effectively manage any identified risks. This includes considering their platform’s design, functionalities, algorithms, and any other features likely to meet the illegal content and child safety duties.
The law also makes it clear that harm can arise from the way content is disseminated, such as when an algorithm repeatedly pushes content to a child in large volumes over a short space of time.
Categorised services will be required to publish annual transparency reports containing online safety related information, such as information about the algorithms they use and their effect on users’ experience, including children.
Much of the most harmful illegal online content disproportionately affects women and girls, and the Act requires platforms to proactively tackle this. Illegal content includes harassment, stalking, controlling or coercive behaviour, extreme pornography, and intimate image abuse.
All user-to-user and search services have duties to put in place systems and processes to remove this content when it is flagged to them. The measures companies must take to remove illegal content will be set out in Ofcom ’s codes of practice.
When developing these codes, Ofcom is required to consult with the Victim’s Commissioner and Domestic Abuse Commissioner to guarantee that the voices and views of women, girls and victims are reflected.
The Act also requires Ofcom to produce guidance that summarises in one clear place the measures that can be taken to tackle the abuse that women and girls disproportionately face online. This guidance will ensure it is easy for platforms to implement holistic and effective protections for women and girls across their various duties. On 25 February, Ofcom published their draft guidance for consultation. This guidance will be subject to a 12-week consultation with finalised guidance published by the end of the year. All companies in scope of the Act should refer to this guidance when implementing protections for users.
The Online Safety Act takes a proportionate approach to mis- and disinformation by focusing on addressing the greatest risks of harm to users, whilst protecting freedom of expression.
Mis- and disinformation will be captured by the Online Safety Act where it is illegal or harmful to children. Services will be required to take steps to remove illegal disinformation content if they become aware of it on their services. This includes the removal of illegal, state-sponsored disinformation through the Foreign Interference Offence, forcing companies to take action against a range of state-sponsored disinformation and state-linked interference online. Companies must also assess whether their service is likely to be accessed by children and, if so deliver additional protections for them. This includes protections against in-scope mis- and disinformation.
Category 1 services will also need to remove certain types of mis- and disinformation if they are prohibited in their terms of services.
The Online Safety Act also requires Ofcom to establish an advisory committee on disinformation and misinformation to build cross-sector understanding of mis- and disinformation. The advisory committee has now appointed a Chair and plans to have its first meeting in April 2025.
The past 2 decades have seen a dramatic change in the way we consume media and interact with content online. We need to ensure pornography regulation and legislation reflects this change.
Separate to the Online Safety Act, the Independent Pornography Review was announced to assess the regulation, legislation and enforcement of online and offline pornographic content.
Since December 2023, the Review was led by the Independent Lead Reviewer, Baroness Gabby Bertin.  The Independent Pornography Review’s final report and its recommendations to government were published on 27 February 2025. The findings of the Review continue to be assessed by the government.

      "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/ai-opportunities-action-plan/ai-opportunities-action-plan#foreword-by-the-secretary-of-state-for-science-innovation-and-technology",
      "acceptedAnswer": {
        "@type": "Answer",
        "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/ai-opportunities-action-plan/ai-opportunities-action-plan#foreword-by-the-secretary-of-state-for-science-innovation-and-technology",
        "text": "\u003cfigure class=\"image embedded\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"img\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/677e81e722a085c5ff5c04ae/sos_kyle_gov.uk.svg\" alt=\"\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\u003cp\u003eToday, Britain is the third largest \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e market in the world. We are home to an extraordinary array of global talent and pioneering \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e firms like Google DeepMind, ARM, and Wayve. But despite our record of scientific discovery - from Alan Turing on algorithms and general-purpose computing to Tim Berners-Lee’s World Wide Web - the UK risks falling behind the advances in Artificial Intelligence made in the USA and China.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn this next phase of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e development, we want Britain to step up; to shape the \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e revolution rather than wait to see how it shapes us. Because we believe Britain has a particular responsibility to provide global leadership in fairly and effectively seizing the opportunities of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e, as we have done on \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e safety. That is why one of my first acts as Secretary of State was to commission Matt Clifford to devise an \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e Opportunities Action Plan for the British government.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis plan shows how we can shape the application of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e within a modern social market economy. We will do so by working closely with the world’s leading \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e companies, Britain’s world leading academics and entrepreneurs, and those talented individuals keen to start-up and scale-up their businesses here. Our ambition is to shape the \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e revolution on principles of shared economic prosperity, improved public services and increased personal opportunities so that:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e drives the economic growth on which the prosperity of our people and the performance of our public services depend;\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e directly benefits working people by improving health care and education and how citizens interact with their government; and\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003ethe increasing of prevalence of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e in people’s working lives opens up new opportunities rather than just threatens traditional patterns of work.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003eAcross government, we have already taken decisive action to support the \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e sector and take down the barriers to growth. Our transformative planning reforms will make it easier to build the data centres that are the engines of the \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e age. Skills England will help ensure that British people are prepared for jobs in the \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e-powered industries of tomorrow. The Digital Centre of Government I have created in my Department will drive forward the technological transformation of the state, ensuring that public services offer citizens the same seamless experience they can find in the private sector.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe recommendations in this plan are unapologetic in their ambition; Government must be the same. Delivering our \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e vision for Britain requires lots of hard work, some tough choices, and a commitment to real partnership between public and private sectors. There’s no time to waste. Today, we have set out how we will rise to the challenge.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe \u003cabbr title=\"The Right Honourable\"\u003eRt Hon\u003c/abbr\u003e Peter Kyle MP\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eSecretary of State for Science, Innovation and Technology\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"
      }
