    {
      "@type": "Question",
      "name": "The opportunity",
      "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/ai-opportunities-action-plan/ai-opportunities-action-plan#the-opportunity",
      "acceptedAnswer": {
        "@type": "Answer",
        "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/ai-opportunities-action-plan/ai-opportunities-action-plan#the-opportunity",
        "text": "\u003cp\u003e\u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e capabilities are developing at an extraordinary pace. If this continues, artificial intelligence (\u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e) could be the government’s single biggest lever to deliver its \u003ca href=\"https://www.gov.uk/missions\"\u003efive missions\u003c/a\u003e, especially the goal of kickstarting broad-based economic growth. It is hard to imagine how we will meet the ambition for highest sustained growth in the \u003cabbr title=\"Group of Seven\"\u003eG7\u003c/abbr\u003e - and the countless quality-of-life benefits that flow from that - without embracing the opportunities of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAny national \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e plan needs to be founded on a realistic assessment of the country’s strengths and weaknesses. Fortunately, the UK has solid - and in places genuinely world-leading - foundations on which to build:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eStrong fundamental \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e research, and high-quality research and engineering talent coming out of our universities, which are some of the best in the world for \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eA vibrant startup and scaleup scene, with an increasingly skilled and experienced entrepreneurial workforce and growing quantities of sophisticated capital available for ambitious companies.\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eLeading frontier \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e companies in London, including Google DeepMind’s headquarters, significant OpenAI, Anthropic, Microsoft and Meta \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e offices, as well as emerging local winners - such as Wayve, the autonomous vehicle company.\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eGlobal leadership on \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e safety and governance via the \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e Safety Institute, and a proportionate, flexible regulatory approach.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003eThese are all crucial prerequisites to making the most of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e opportunities; without them, the ambition in this plan would not be credible. However, we cannot be complacent: to remain a world leader we need to lead in both building and using \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e. Our goal should be a thriving domestic \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e ecosystem, with serious players at multiple layers of the “\u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e stack” and widespread use of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e products and services across the economy.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe UK’s starting point makes this aspiration plausible, but achieving it will require bold and visionary action. The government must:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eInvest in the foundations of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e:\u003c/strong\u003e We need world-class computing and data infrastructure, access to talent and regulation (\u003ca href=\"#lay-the-foundations\"\u003eSection 1\u003c/a\u003e).\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003ePush hard on cross-economy \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e adoption:\u003c/strong\u003e The public sector should rapidly pilot and scale \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e products and services and encourage the private sector to do the same. This will drive better experiences and outcomes for citizens and boost productivity (\u003ca href=\"#changes-lives\"\u003eSection 2\u003c/a\u003e).\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003ePosition the UK to be an \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e maker, not an \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e taker:\u003c/strong\u003e As the technology becomes more powerful, we should be the best state partner to those building frontier \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e. The UK should aim to have true national champions at critical layers of the \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e stack so that the UK benefits economically from \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e advancement and has influence on future \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e’s values, safety and governance (\u003ca href=\"#secure-future\"\u003eSection 3\u003c/a\u003e).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis Action Plan is made up of three sections - one for each of these goals. There are detailed recommendations in each. In making them, I have tried to draw consistently on a small number of core principles:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eBe on the side of innovators: In every element of the Action Plan, the government should ask itself: does this benefit people and organisations trying to do new and ambitious things in the UK? If not, we will fail to meet our potential.\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eInvest in becoming a great customer: government purchasing power can be a huge lever for improving public services, shaping new markets in \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e, and boosting the domestic ecosystem. But doing this well is not easy - it will require real leadership and radical change, especially in procurement.\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eCrowd in capital and talent: The UK is a medium-sized country with a tight fiscal situation. We need the best talent around the world to want to start and scale companies here. If we do that, the best investors globally will want to deploy capital here - both into our startups and our \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e infrastructure.\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eBuild on UK strengths and catalytic emerging areas: The UK has strong companies in the \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e application and integration layers that are well positioned to grow. We also have emerging areas of research and engineering strength - particularly in \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e for science and robotics - that could have a transformational impact across the economy, advance \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e and unlock further innovation.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003eNo one can say with certainty what \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e will look like a decade from now. My judgement is that experts, on balance, expect rapid progress to continue. The risks from underinvesting and underpreparing, though, seem much greater than the risks from the opposite. Even if \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e progress slows, we will see large benefits from deploying today’s frontier capabilities and investing in our infrastructure and talent base.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIf, however, capabilities continue to advance, having a stake in - and being the natural home of - advanced \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e could be the difference between shaping the future of science, technology and work  and seeing these decisions made entirely outside our borders. This is a crucial asymmetric bet - and one the UK can and must make .\u003c/p\u003e"
      }
    },
    {
      "@type": "Question",
      "name": "1. Lay the foundations to enable AI\n",
      "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/ai-opportunities-action-plan/ai-opportunities-action-plan#lay-the-foundations",
      "acceptedAnswer": {
        "@type": "Answer",
        "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/ai-opportunities-action-plan/ai-opportunities-action-plan#lay-the-foundations",
        "text": "\u003ch3 id=\"building-sufficient-secure-and-sustainable-ai-infrastructure\"\u003e1.1 Building sufficient, secure and sustainable \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e Infrastructure\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe foundation of the last decade of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e progress has been an extraordinary and sustained investment in computational power (often called “compute”). \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e requires data centres that house the large and complex computers that are used to train \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e models and to run ‘inference’ (where \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e is used to complete tasks and answer queries).\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eOf course, the UK does not need to own or operate all the compute it will need. Indeed, only a small fraction of our needs will be through such compute (though this fraction is important). A decade from now the economy will almost certainly be more computationally intensive: new high-skill jobs and compute-adjacent industries will have been created and access to compute will be a key pillar of economic security. Countries that enable the build out of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e infrastructure will reap benefits through increased economic growth, the reinvigoration of former industrial sites and ownership of critical strategic assets.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe availability of powerful computing resources sends an important signal to academic, technical and entrepreneurial talent and is a critical ingredient of innovation. We should expect enormous improvements in computation over the next decade, both in research and deployment. Having this “learning by doing” happen in the UK is crucial if we want the industries of the future to be built here.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe government must therefore secure access to a sufficient supply of compute. There is no precise mechanism to allocate the proportions, but it should consist of:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eSovereign \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e compute, owned and/or allocated by the public sector, will enable the UK to quickly and independently allocate compute to national priorities. For example, we need the ability to: drive mission-focused \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e research; empower academics and startups to train \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e models; and ensure access to \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e compute for critical services in times of market disruption. Sovereign \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e compute will almost certainly be the smallest component of the UK’s overall compute portfolio. NB: this review has not considered the requirements of non-\u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e high-performance computing, for which there is already a well-established case, including the need to deliver an exascale capability. Government should seek to resolve this as soon as possible, noting that these systems will play a crucial role in supporting \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e science and research.\u003c/p\u003e\n  \u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eDomestic compute, that is based within the UK but privately owned and operated and that will position the UK as a leading \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e economy and ensure the UK’s economic security. Due to the criticality of compute for \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e, domestic compute will create spillover benefits in the form of jobs, investment and new, \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e based, service businesses. In this part of the portfolio, crowding in private and international capital is critical.\u003c/p\u003e\n  \u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eInternational compute, accessed via reciprocal agreements and partnerships with like-minded partners, to give the UK access to complementary capabilities and facilitate joint \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e research in areas of shared interest. We should proactively develop these partnerships, while also taking an active role in the EuroHPC Joint Undertaking.\u003c/p\u003e\n  \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003eTo achieve this, government should:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e1. \u003cstrong\u003eSet out, within 6 months, a long-term plan for the UK’s \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e infrastructure needs, backed by a 10-year investment commitment.\u003c/strong\u003e Building a world class \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e compute ecosystem requires a clear objective and long-term capability and expertise. Government should consider what the most appropriate delivery body is for large scale research infrastructure that is delivered in partnership with universities and industry. We have pockets of deep academic expertise in this space, such as at Edinburgh, Bristol and Cambridge universities, and we should draw on this. A credible plan will consider emerging compute technologies, include investment in software, skills, and wider high-performance computing capabilities to complement our \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e compute and enable \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e for science.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e2. \u003cstrong\u003eExpand the capacity of the \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e Research Resource (\u003cabbr title=\"AI Research Resource\"\u003eAIRR\u003c/abbr\u003e) by at least 20x by 2030 - starting within 6 months.\u003c/strong\u003e The \u003cabbr title=\"AI Research Resource\"\u003eAIRR\u003c/abbr\u003e should evolve into a set of mission-oriented clusters that bring together compute, data, and talent to pursue frontier \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e research and other national priorities. Expansion by at least 20x by 2030 would ensure the \u003cabbr title=\"AI Research Resource\"\u003eAIRR\u003c/abbr\u003e enables the training of multiple \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e models a year and provides an up to date research capability.\u003csup id=\"fnref:1\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:1\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 1]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e Given trends in hardware performance, this would not mean a 20x increase in investment if the government procures smartly.\u003csup id=\"fnref:2\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:2\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 2]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e Such expansion is needed to keep up with the expected increases in computing power that we should assume will be needed for \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e workloads. This is unlikely to slow down; we need to “run to stand still”. As part of this, government should ensure that the public compute ecosystem hosts a range of hardware providers to avoid vendor lock-in and ensure value for money.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e3. \u003cstrong\u003eStrategically allocate sovereign compute by appointing mission-focused “\u003cabbr title=\"AI Research Resource\"\u003eAIRR\u003c/abbr\u003e programme directors” with significant autonomy.\u003c/strong\u003e These could be modelled after the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (\u003cabbr title=\"Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency\"\u003eDARPA\u003c/abbr\u003e) or the Advanced Research and Invention Agency (ARIA) to quickly and independently provide large amounts of compute to high-potential projects of national importance, operating in a way that is strategic and mission driven. Allocation is an essential part of any compute strategy: spreading large amounts of compute thinly will have little impact. We will have to make choices about when to subsidise compute and when to provide it at cost, recognising that this could form part of an attractive offer to entrepreneurs and researchers deciding where to base themselves.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e4. \u003cstrong\u003eEstablish ‘\u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e Growth Zones’ (AIGZs) to facilitate the accelerated build out of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e data centres.\u003c/strong\u003e As \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e infrastructure providers seek access to land and power, governments who move quickly and mirror the pace of growth and innovation in the \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e data centre market will be best placed to secure investment. AIGZs could introduce a streamlined planning approvals process and accelerate the provisioning of clean power. This is a major opportunity to crowd in private capital to boost our domestic compute portfolio and to build strategic partnerships with \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e developers to work on shared \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e and \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e-enabled priorities. Government can also use AIGZs to drive local rejuvenation, channelling investment into areas with existing energy capacity such as post-industrial towns and coastal Scotland. Government should quickly nominate at least one \u003cabbr title=\"AI Growth Zones\"\u003eAIGZ\u003c/abbr\u003e and work with local regions to secure buy-in for further AIGZs that contribute to local needs. Existing government sites could be prioritised as pilots, including Culham Science Centre, the UK Atomic Energy Authority’s headquarters, which has access to significant power and land. Alongside this, government should consider other measures to accelerate buildout of data centres, such as offering central guidance, creating a bespoke planning use-class and considering the case for \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e data centres to be eligible for relevant relief schemes that incentivise private sector investment.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e5. \u003cstrong\u003eMitigate the sustainability and security risks of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e infrastructure, while positioning the UK to take advantage of opportunities to provide solutions.\u003c/strong\u003e This should focus both on secure private-sector compute as well as collaboration with the UK Intelligence Community. Government should also explore ways to support novel approaches to compute hardware and, where appropriate, create partitions in national supercomputers to support new and innovative hardware. In doing so, government should look to support and partner with UK companies who can demonstrate performance, sustainability or security advancements.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e6. \u003cstrong\u003eAgree international compute partnerships with like-minded countries to increase the types of compute capability available to researchers and catalyse research collaborations.\u003c/strong\u003e This should focus on building arrangements with key allies, as well as expanding collaboration with existing partners like the EuroHPC Joint Undertaking.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3 id=\"unlocking-data-assets-in-the-public-and-private-sector\"\u003e1.2 Unlocking data assets in the public and private sector\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eTo fuel both frontier \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e progress and high-quality \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e applications, developers need access to high-quality data - the lifeblood of modern \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e. Data that isn’t in the training sets of current models and encodes new insights about the world is particularly valuable. Public data sets, including scientific data sets, may be extremely important in this context.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe should seek to responsibly unlock both public and private data sets to enable innovation by UK startups and researchers and to attract international talent and capital. As part of this, government needs to develop a more sophisticated understanding of the value of the data it holds, how this value can be responsibly realised, and how to ensure the preservation of public trust across all its work to unlock its data assets.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe creation of the National Data Library (\u003cabbr title=\"National Data Library\"\u003eNDL\u003c/abbr\u003e) presents an enormous opportunity. As it develops the \u003cabbr title=\"National Data Library\"\u003eNDL\u003c/abbr\u003e, the government should:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e7. \u003cstrong\u003eRapidly identify at least 5 high-impact public datasets it will seek to make available to \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e researchers and innovators.\u003c/strong\u003e Prioritisation should consider the potential economic and social value of the data, as well as public trust, national security, privacy, ethics, and data protection considerations. We should explore use of synthetic data generation techniques to construct privacy-preserving versions of highly sensitive data sets. Government data sets are a public asset, and careful consideration should be given to their valuation.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e8. \u003cstrong\u003eStrategically shape what data is collected, rather than just making data available that already exists.\u003c/strong\u003e Government should look to collect data in strategically significant areas, building on existing UK strengths. For example, the \u003cabbr title=\"National Data Library\"\u003eNDL\u003c/abbr\u003e could build on the achievements of the UK Biobank to enhance research in areas such as disease recognition and the prediction of health outcomes. The \u003cabbr title=\"National Data Library\"\u003eNDL\u003c/abbr\u003e should run open calls to receive proposals from researchers and industry to propose new data sets.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e9. \u003cstrong\u003eDevelop and publish guidelines and best practices for releasing open government datasets which can be used for \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e, including on the development of effective data structures and data dissemination methods.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e10. \u003cstrong\u003eCouple compute allocation with access to proprietary data sets\u003c/strong\u003e as part of an attractive offer to researchers and start-ups choosing to establish themselves in the UK and to unlock innovation.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e11. \u003cstrong\u003eBuild public sector data collection infrastructure and finance the creation of new high-value datasets that meet public sector, academia and startup needs.\u003c/strong\u003e Government should identify how public data will be collected and its quality enhanced, including the use of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e-driven data cleansing tools to curate data sets stored across government, making them suitable for \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e developers and researchers.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e12. \u003cstrong\u003eActively incentivise and reward researchers and industry to curate and unlock private datasets.\u003c/strong\u003e In particular, the \u003cabbr title=\"National Data Library\"\u003eNDL\u003c/abbr\u003e should engage with UKRI to identify how the creation of valuable high-quality data sets that support the research community could be better acknowledged via the Research Excellence Framework. Government should also explore how to shape the market in data set curation, including contributions from the private sector.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e13. \u003cstrong\u003eEstablish a copyright-cleared British media asset training data set,\u003c/strong\u003e which can be licensed internationally at scale. This could be done through partnering with bodies that hold valuable cultural data like the National Archives, Natural History Museum, British Library and the BBC to develop a commercial proposition for sharing their data to advance \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3 id=\"training-attracting-and-retaining-the-next-generation-of-ai-scientists-and-founders\"\u003e1.3 Training, attracting and retaining the next generation of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e scientists and founders\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eIf we want the UK to have both world-class \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e research and a world-leading \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e application ecosystem, we need to be the natural home for elite talent. In the next 5 years, the UK must be prepared to train tens of thousands of additional \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e professionals across the technology stack to meet expected demand and proactively increase its share of the world’s top 1,000 \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e researchers.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn the long-term, government needs to create a deeper pool of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e skills and talent that will build, diffuse and use \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e products across the economy.\u003csup id=\"fnref:3\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:3\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 3]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e Setting a short-term target to train tens of thousands of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e professionals by 2030 will help bridge the estimated gap between supply and demand.\u003csup id=\"fnref:4\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:4\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 4]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e This would put the UK in step with countries like France, whose National \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e Commission calculates that the number of French \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e graduates would need to triple over the next decade to match estimated demand.\u003csup id=\"fnref:5\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:5\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 5]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAs a priority first step, government should:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e14. \u003cstrong\u003eAccurately assess the size of the skills gap.\u003c/strong\u003e Current estimates are imprecise and outdated; the last government-funded \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e labour market survey was in 2020 and the Unit for Future Skills’ jobs and skills dashboard, while a step in the right direction, still uses supply data from 2019.\u003csup id=\"fnref:6\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:6\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 6]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e The success of the following recommendations depends on accurately understanding the skills gap, and so government must make efforts to come to a concrete and up-to-date number.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eOnce the size of the skills gap is confirmed, to reach this target over the next 5 years government should:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e15. \u003cstrong\u003eSupport Higher Education Institutions to increase the numbers of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e graduates and teach industry-relevant skills.\u003c/strong\u003e In 2022, 46,000 students graduated from an \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e-relevant higher education programme in the UK. While this is the highest in Europe, with Germany (32,000) second, the UK is behind Finland and others on a per capita basis and there remains unmet demand for skilled workers.\u003csup id=\"fnref:7\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:7\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 7]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e Supporting universities to develop new courses co-designed with industry - such as the successful co-operative education model of Canada’s University of Waterloo, \u003cabbr title=\"Center for Digital Technology and Management\"\u003eCDTM\u003c/abbr\u003e at the Technical University of Munich or France’s CIFRE PhD model - and increasing their teaching and recruitment capacity would help train the tens of thousands of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e professionals needed by 2030.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e16. \u003cstrong\u003eIncrease the diversity of the talent pool.\u003c/strong\u003e Only 22% of people working in \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e and data science are women.\u003csup id=\"fnref:8\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:8\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 8]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e Achieving parity would mean thousands of additional workers. The \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e conversion courses have helped to diversify the \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e pipeline, but only at the top end. Government should build on this investment and promote diversity throughout the education pipeline. Interventions must be tailored - there is no one-size-fits-all approach. Hackathons and competitions in schools have proven effective at getting overlooked groups into cyber and so should be considered for \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e.\u003csup id=\"fnref:9\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:9\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 9]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e17. \u003cstrong\u003eExpand education pathways into \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e.\u003c/strong\u003e Higher education is the most common pathway into \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e careers and will likely remain so at least until 2030.\u003csup id=\"fnref:10\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:10\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 10]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e To meet the demands of the labour market and the changing skills needs of the future, however, government should encourage and promote alternative domestic routes into the \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e profession - including through further education and apprenticeships, as well as employer and self-led upskilling.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e18. \u003cstrong\u003eLaunch a flagship undergraduate and masters \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e scholarship programme on the scale of Rhodes, Marshall, or Fulbright for students to study in the UK.\u003c/strong\u003e  Open to a diverse initial cohort of 100 scholars from the UK and abroad, the programme would combine financial support, cohort building, industry co-investment, and placements in government or private sector \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e organisations. Potential scholars must show exceptional promise, but recognising the broad range of talents needed for success in \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e, this could be in a variety of fields, such as strong performance in a leading STEM competition (e.g. the International Mathematical or Informatics Olympiads).\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e19. \u003cstrong\u003eEnsure its lifelong skills programme is ready for \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e.\u003c/strong\u003e \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e will continue to change the labour market, though exactly how and when is unclear. What is certain is while some jobs will be replaced by \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e, many will be augmented - and an unknown number will be created. Government should ensure there are sufficient opportunities for workers to reskill, both into \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e and \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e-enabled jobs and more widely. The UK should also learn and adopt best practice from other countries who are preparing their skills systems for the long-term impacts of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e. Singapore, for example, developed a national \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e skills online platform with multiple training offers. South Korea is integrating \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e, data and digital literacy throughout its education pipelines through an \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e curriculum and a variety of training and education programmes. Skills England and the independent Curriculum and Assessment Review present an opportunity to consider the merit of such approaches in our system.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAlongside these longer-term investments, the government’s priority should be to rapidly increase the number of top \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e research talents who work in the UK. These leading \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e scientists and engineers are few in number and highly prized globally. The countries that attract them will play an outsized role in the future of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e. It is not surprising that the US, which is the number 1 destination for top talent, has also been at the forefront of recent \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e breakthroughs.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eInternational competition for top talent is fierce. The UK must go further than existing measures and take a more proactive approach at every stage of the talent pipeline. Though ambitious, these efforts could yield large benefits for the UK if one individual founds the next DeepMind or OpenAI.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWithin the next year, government should:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e20. \u003cstrong\u003eEstablish an internal headhunting capability on a par with top \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e firms to bring a small number of elite individuals to the UK.\u003c/strong\u003e Government should build on the success of the \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e Safety Institute in attracting top talent. This may include recruiting more people into \u003cabbr title=\"AI Safety Institute\"\u003eAISI\u003c/abbr\u003e, UK Sovereign \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e or other public \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e labs, as well as UK-based companies. Officials will need flexibility to develop specific offers and provide wraparound support to talent targets - recognising that to truly ‘headhunt’ talent the programme will need to be backed by appropriate funding.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e21. \u003cstrong\u003eExplore how the existing immigration system can be used to attract graduates from universities producing some of the world’s top \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e talent.\u003c/strong\u003e Graduates from some leading \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e institutions, such as the Indian Institutes of Technology and (since 2020) Carnegie Mellon University in the US, are not currently included in the High Potential Individual visa eligibility list. Government should take steps to develop new pathways, and strengthen existing ones, to support these graduates. It should also explore how best to address wider barriers like the cost and complexity of visas which create obstacles for startups and deter overseas talent from re-locating to the UK.\u003csup id=\"fnref:11\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:11\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 11]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e22. \u003cstrong\u003eExpand the Turing \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e Fellowship offer.\u003c/strong\u003e 15 new Turing \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e Pioneer Fellowships should be created for specialists in other sectors who wish to develop deep technical skills in \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e. At the same time, funding for 25 more Turing \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e Acceleration and \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e World-Leading fellowships should be committed to maintain the current cohort size over the next 3 years, as existing fellows graduate from the programme.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3 id=\"enabling-safe-and-trusted-ai-development-and-adoption-through-regulation-safety-and-assurance\"\u003e1.4 Enabling safe and trusted \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e development and adoption through regulation, safety and assurance\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe UK’s current pro-innovation approach to regulation is a source of strength relative to other more regulated jurisdictions and we should be careful to preserve this.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWell-designed and implemented regulation, alongside effective assurance tools, can fuel fast, wide and safe development and adoption of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e. Regulators themselves have an important role in supporting innovation as part of their Growth Duty. Government must protect UK citizens from the most significant risks presented by \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e and foster public trust in the technology, particularly considering the interests of marginalised groups. That said, we must do this without blocking the path towards \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e’s transformative potential.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIneffective regulation could hold back adoption in crucial sectors like the medical sector, but regulation, safety and assurance have the power to drive innovation and economic growth too, as shown by the success of regulatory sandboxes in supporting fintech startups and the development of the UK’s cyber security industry.\u003csup id=\"fnref:12\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:12\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 12]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e Clear rules provide clarity to businesses so they have the confidence to invest and bring new products and services to market.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe government should:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e23. \u003cstrong\u003eContinue to support and grow the \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e Safety Institute (\u003cabbr title=\"AI Safety Institute\"\u003eAISI\u003c/abbr\u003e) to maintain and expand its research on model evaluations, foundational safety and societal resilience research.\u003c/strong\u003e \u003cabbr title=\"AI Safety Institute\"\u003eAISI\u003c/abbr\u003e is the first safety institute to have conducted pre-deployment evaluations of frontier models and its success is a significant and growing source of international influence for the UK. Continued investment is needed to ensure \u003cabbr title=\"AI Safety Institute\"\u003eAISI\u003c/abbr\u003e retains its position as a world-leader and remains attractive to top \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e safety researchers. It is also essential to act quickly to provide clarity on how frontier models will be regulated. A top priority of any such regulation should be preserving the capability, trust and collaboration that the \u003cabbr title=\"AI Safety Institute\"\u003eAISI\u003c/abbr\u003e has built up since its creation.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e24. \u003cstrong\u003eReform the UK text and data mining regime so that it is at least as competitive as the EU.\u003c/strong\u003e The current uncertainty around intellectual property (\u003cabbr title=\"intellectual property\"\u003eIP\u003c/abbr\u003e) is hindering innovation and undermining our broader ambitions for \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e, as well as the growth of our creative industries. This has gone on too long and needs to be urgently resolved. The EU has moved forward with an approach that is designed to support \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e innovation while also enabling rights holders to have control over the use of content they produce. The UK is falling behind.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIt is also essential that we act now to ensure sector regulators are fit for the age of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e. In particular, government should:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e25. \u003cstrong\u003eCommit to funding regulators to scale up their \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e capabilities, some of which need urgent addressing.\u003c/strong\u003e Government should also ensure all sponsor departments demonstrate how they are funding this capability within their budgets through the Spending Review process.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e26. \u003cstrong\u003eEnsure all sponsor departments include a focus on enabling safe \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e innovation in their strategic guidance to regulators.\u003c/strong\u003e \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e will touch every aspect of the economy and so it is essential that all regulators are prioritising understanding its impacts in their domains and considering how best to encourage its safe adoption.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e27. \u003cstrong\u003eWork with regulators to accelerate \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e in priority sectors and implement pro-innovation initiatives like regulatory sandboxes.\u003c/strong\u003e These should be targeted in areas with regulatory challenges but high-growth potential, such as products which integrate \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e into the physical world like autonomous vehicles, drones and robotics.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e28. \u003cstrong\u003eRequire all regulators to publish annually how they have enabled innovation and growth driven by \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e in their sector.\u003c/strong\u003e To ensure accountability, this should include transparent metrics such as timelines to publish guidance, make licence decisions and report on resources allocated to \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e-focused work. Even with these initiatives, individual regulators may still lack the incentives to promote innovation at the scale of the government’s ambition. If evidence demonstrates that is the case, government should consider more radical changes to our regulatory model for \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e, for example by empowering a central body with a mandate and higher risk tolerance to promote innovation across the economy. Such a body could have expertise and statutory powers to issue pilot sandbox licences for \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e products that override sector regulations, taking on liability for all related risks. This approach could initially be explored and piloted for specific \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e applications at small scale.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAlongside investing in pro-innovation regulation, the government should:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e29. \u003cstrong\u003eSupport the \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e assurance ecosystem to increase trust and adoption by:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eInvesting significantly in the development of new assurance tools, including through an expansion to \u003cabbr title=\"AI Safety Institute\"\u003eAISI\u003c/abbr\u003e’s systemic \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e safety fast grants programme, to support emerging safety research and methods.\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eBuilding government-backed high-quality assurance tools that assess whether \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e systems perform as claimed and work as intended.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003eAs part of taking forward the recommendations in this Action Plan, government should:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e30. \u003cstrong\u003eConsider the broader institutional landscape and the full potential of the Alan Turing Institute to drive progress at the cutting edge, support the government’s missions and attract international talent.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"
      }

      "@type": "Question",
      "name": "2. Change lives by embracing AI\n",
      "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/ai-opportunities-action-plan/ai-opportunities-action-plan#changes-lives",
      "acceptedAnswer": {
        "@type": "Answer",
        "url": "https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/ai-opportunities-action-plan/ai-opportunities-action-plan#changes-lives",
        "text": "\u003ch3 id=\"ai-adoption-is-core-to-delivering-the-governments-missions\"\u003e2.1  \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e Adoption is core to delivering the government’s missions\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe adoption of high-performing, trustworthy \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e at scale will be critical to the \u003ca href=\"https://www.gov.uk/missions\"\u003egovernment fulfilling the five missions\u003c/a\u003e. \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e should become core to how we think about delivering services, transforming citizens’ experiences, and improving productivity. As well as strengthening the foundations - data, skills, talent, \u003cabbr title=\"intellectual property\"\u003eIP\u003c/abbr\u003e, and assurance measures set out above - government should also focus on its role as a major user and customer of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e and how it uses its powers to catalyse private sector adoption:\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch4 id=\"adoption-missions\"\u003eAdoption missions\u003c/h4\u003e\u003cfigure class=\"image embedded\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"img\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/678120fd153753104a9217dc/adoption-missions.svg\" alt=\"\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\u003cp\u003eThough we are still early in the development of the \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e application layer - and all \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e use should be tailored appropriately to the specific setting or sector in which it will be deployed. For example, \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e use in health and care will raise different considerations than in advanced manufacturing. Indeed there are already great examples of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e use-cases driving tangible benefits across the private and public sectors:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eUsing \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e assistants\u003c/strong\u003e to do repetitive tasks better and faster, freeing up to 20% of an employee’s time.\u003csup id=\"fnref:13\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:13\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 13]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e For example, it is helping some teachers cut down the 15+ hours a week they spend on lesson planning and marking in pilots.\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eDrafting structured reports and forms with \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e can cut final document production times by 20-80% in professional services.\u003csup id=\"fnref:14\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:14\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 14]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e Trials are underway exploring how these methods can save time for clinical practitioners in the NHS.\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eAutomated threat and anomaly detection\u003c/strong\u003e is already being responsibly deployed by police forces across the country and used to clean up social media.\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eAssessment and diagnosis\u003c/strong\u003e can be improved through the use of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e. For example, through the £21 million \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e Diagnostics fund, Department for Health and Social Care (\u003cabbr title=\"Department for Health and Social Care\"\u003eDHSC\u003c/abbr\u003e) is supporting the deployment of technologies in key, high-demand areas such as chest X-Ray and chest \u003cabbr title=\"Computed Tomography\"\u003eCT\u003c/abbr\u003e scans to enable faster diagnosis and treatment of lung cancer in over half of acute trusts in England. Assessments can be done better, cheaper, and more quickly across multiple sectors. We also anticipate that \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e will be a useful tool for assessment in the education sector. For example, the Department for Education’s generative \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e and rules-based marking tool showed 92% accuracy in a pilot with teachers on year 4 literacy work when drawing from appropriately coded educational data and content.\u003csup id=\"fnref:15\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:15\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 15]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003ch3 id=\"adopt-a-scan--pilot--scale-approach-in-government\"\u003e2.2 Adopt a “Scan \u0026gt; Pilot \u0026gt; Scale” approach in government\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhile there are instances of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e being used well across the public sector, often they are at small scale and in silos. Scaling these successes is essential, but will require us to think differently about procurement, especially if this activity is to support the domestic startup and innovation ecosystem. As the digital centre of government, \u003cabbr title=\"Department for Science, Innovation and Technology\"\u003eDSIT\u003c/abbr\u003e should support public sector partners where needed to “move fast and learn things”.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eGovernment should generally employ a flexible “Scan \u0026gt; Pilot \u0026gt; Scale” approach.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"call-to-action\"\u003e\n  \u003ch4 id=\"scan\"\u003eScan\u003c/h4\u003e\n\n  \u003cp\u003eInvesting in building a deep and continually updated understanding of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e capabilities mapped to their highest impact challenges and opportunities. This will require:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n  \u003cp\u003e31. \u003cstrong\u003eAppointing an \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e lead for each mission to help identify where \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e could be a solution within the mission setting, considering the user needs from the outset.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n  \u003cp\u003e32. \u003cstrong\u003eA cross government, technical horizon scanning and market intelligence capability who understands \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e capabilities and use-cases as they evolve to work closely with the mission leads and maximise the expertise of both.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n  \u003cp\u003e33. \u003cstrong\u003eTwo-way partnerships with \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e vendors and startups to anticipate future \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e developments and signal public sector demand.\u003c/strong\u003e This would involve government meeting product teams to understand upcoming releases and shape development by sharing their challenges.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"call-to-action\"\u003e\n  \u003ch4 id=\"pilot\"\u003ePilot\u003c/h4\u003e\n\n  \u003cp\u003eRapidly developing prototypes or fast light-touch procurement to spin up pilots in high-impact areas, robust evaluation and publishing results. This will require:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n  \u003cp\u003e34. \u003cstrong\u003eConsistent use of a framework for how to source \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e - whether to build in-house, buy, or run innovation challenges - that evolves over time, given data, capability, industry contexts and evaluation of what’s worked.\u003c/strong\u003e Where appropriate, the government should support open-source solutions that can be adopted by other organisations and design processes with startups and other innovators in mind.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n  \u003cp\u003e35. \u003cstrong\u003eA rapid prototyping capability that can be drawn on for key projects where needed, including technical and delivery resource to build and test proof of concepts, leveraging in-house \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e expertise, together with specialists in design and user experience.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n  \u003cp\u003e36. \u003cstrong\u003eSpecific support to hire external \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e talent.\u003c/strong\u003e Creation of a technical senior civil servant stream, benchmarking of internal \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e-related role pay to at least 75% of private-sector rate and a technical \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e recruitment screening process.\u003csup id=\"fnref:16\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:16\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 16]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n  \u003cp\u003e37. \u003cstrong\u003eA data-rich experimentation environment including a streamlined approach to accessing data sets, access to language models and necessary infrastructure like compute.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n  \u003cp\u003e38. \u003cstrong\u003eA faster, multi-stage gated and scaling \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e procurement process that enables easy and quick access to small-scale funding for pilots and only layers bureaucratic controls as the investment-size gets larger.\u003c/strong\u003e Multi-staged “Competitive Flexible Procedures” should be encouraged, and startups compensated for the rounds they make it through.\u003csup id=\"fnref:17\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:17\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 17]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"call-to-action\"\u003e\n  \u003ch4 id=\"scale\"\u003eScale\u003c/h4\u003e\n\n  \u003cp\u003eIdentifying successful pilots that can be applied in different settings to support citizens (e.g. to reduce waiting lists or minimise time and cost to complete paperwork) and rolling them out beyond organisational boundaries. Scale is essential if \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e is to have a meaningful impact on productivity, effectiveness and citizen experience, as well as maximising government spending power. Moreover, doing this well and procuring in a way that benefits innovators is a powerful lever for upending the cliché that the UK is good at invention, but poor at commercialisation. It will require:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n  \u003cp\u003e39. \u003cstrong\u003eA scaling service for successful pilots with senior support and central funding resource.\u003c/strong\u003e The government should support a select number of proven pilots to scale - with central finance and tools available to avoid fragmentation across systems and budgets - and achieve up to national level reach.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n  \u003cp\u003e40. \u003cstrong\u003eMission-focussed national \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e tenders to support rapid adoption across de-centralised systems led by the mission delivery boards.\u003c/strong\u003e An example of tendering to enable scale is the NHS’s \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e Diagnostic Fund allocating £21 million to twelve imaging networks, covering 66 NHS trusts across England, significantly speeding up the roll out of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e diagnostic tools nationwide.\u003csup id=\"fnref:18\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:18\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 18]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e However, these tenders should be designed to encourage new entrants, avoiding reliance on commercial frameworks where possible.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n  \u003cp\u003e41. \u003cstrong\u003eDevelopment or procurement of a scalable \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e tech stack that supports the use of specialist narrow and large language models for tens or hundreds of millions of citizen interactions across the UK.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n  \u003cp\u003e42. \u003cstrong\u003eMandating infrastructure interoperability, code reusability and open sourcing.\u003c/strong\u003e The \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e infrastructure choice at-scale should be standardised, tools should be built with reusable modular code components, and code-base open-sourcing where possible.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003ch3 id=\"enable-public-and-private-sectors-to-reinforce-each-other\"\u003e2.3 Enable public and private sectors to reinforce each other\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe public and private sectors should play mutually reinforcing roles in \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e adoption. To get the most from working together, government should:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e43. \u003cstrong\u003eProcure smartly from the \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e ecosystem as both its largest customer and as a market shaper.\u003c/strong\u003e Innovative \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e suppliers from the UK and around the world should be engaged to support demand and encourage investment. Procurement contract terms should set standards (e.g. quality), requirements, and best practice (e.g. performance evaluations). “Contemplation” clauses should be included in contracts to ensure the government remains agile to a rapidly changing \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e ecosystem by mandating that contractors regularly assess and adopt newer technologies.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e44. \u003cstrong\u003eUse digital government infrastructure to create new opportunities for innovators.\u003c/strong\u003e For example, an approach akin to Jeff Bezos’s API mandate at Amazon could be adopted. This required all teams’ data and functionality to be exposed through APIs (Application Programme Interfaces). All standard documentation interactions, like compliance or planning, could be done through APIs, to which companies could connect their own tools. Similarly, mandating e-Invoices from government suppliers could automate billing, speed up payments and reduce fraud.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e45. \u003cstrong\u003ePublish best-practice guidance, results, case-studies and open-source solutions through a single “\u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e Knowledge Hub”\u003c/strong\u003e accessible to technical and non-technical users across private and public sectors as a single place to access frameworks and insights.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e46. \u003cstrong\u003eIn the next 3 months, the Digital Centre of Government should identify a series of quick wins to support the adoption of the scan, pilot scale approach and enable public and private sector to reinforce each other.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3 id=\"address-private-sector-user-adoption-barriers\"\u003e2.4 Address private-sector-user-adoption barriers\u003c/h3\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e adoption could grow the UK economy by an additional £400 billion by 2030 through enhancing innovation and productivity in the workplace.\u003csup id=\"fnref:19\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"#fn:19\" class=\"footnote\" rel=\"footnote\" role=\"doc-noteref\"\u003e[footnote 19]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e Safe, effective and swift \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e adoption has the potential to enhance the international competitiveness of sectors of UK strength and unlock new growth opportunities across the whole economy, including for \u003cabbr title=\"Small and medium-sized enterprises\"\u003eSMEs\u003c/abbr\u003e. To capture the benefits of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e adoption across the private sector, the government should:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e47. \u003cstrong\u003eLeverage the new Industrial Strategy. The development of a new Industrial Strategy presents an opportunity to drive collective action to support \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e adoption across the economy.\u003c/strong\u003e  The Industrial Strategy will need to set out how \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e adoption can best be supported in key industries, noting particular use cases that could boost productivity and present a particular competitive advantage while also identifying possible regulatory barriers and specific skills needs that need to be addressed. \u003cabbr title=\"Department for Science, Innovation and Technology\"\u003eDSIT\u003c/abbr\u003e and others with \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e expertise within government can play a critical role in combining with those who have a deep understanding of their sectors to engage business leaders, identify high-potential use cases, co-design targeted interventions to promote them and overcome barriers to adopting them.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e48. \u003cstrong\u003eAppoint \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e Sector Champions in key industries like the life sciences, financial services and the creative industries to work with industry and government and develop \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e adoption plans.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e49. \u003cstrong\u003eDrive \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e adoption across the whole country.\u003c/strong\u003e Widespread adoption of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e can address regional disparities in growth and productivity. To achieve this, government should leverage local trusted intermediaries and trade bodies to support business leaders, and also consider opportunities to accelerate \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e adoption by working across supply chains. A particular focus should be put on supporting \u003cabbr title=\"Small and medium-sized enterprises\"\u003eSMEs\u003c/abbr\u003e and the specific challenges they face.\u003c/p\u003e"
      }

        "text": "\u003cp\u003eBy the end of the decade, having national champions at the frontier of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e capabilities may be a critical pillar of our national and economic security. Government should use the full powers it has available to ensure this happens.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e systems are increasingly matching or surpassing humans across a range of tasks. Today’s \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e systems have many limitations, but industry is investing at a scale that assumes capabilities will continue to grow rapidly. Frontier models in 2024 are trained with 10,000x more computing power than in 2019, and we are likely to see a similar rate of growth by 2029. If progress continues at the rate of the last 5 years, by 2029 we can expect \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e to be a dominant factor in economic performance and national security.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eMany of us have become familiar with the remarkable capabilities of large language models across a broad set of domains. Leading \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e companies continue to push this frontier, and we are also seeing stunning progress in other modalities, including breakthroughs in video and image generation, robotics, mathematics, and scientific discovery. To take one example, DeepMind’s AlphaFold - which predicts protein structures - is estimated to have saved the equivalent of 400 million years of researcher time. We can imagine the impact on science, medicine and the broader economy if we see this sort of success in other domains.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eGiven the pace of progress, we will also very soon see agentic systems - systems that can be given an objective, then reason, plan and act to achieve it. The chatbots we are all familiar with are just an early glimpse as to what is possible.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe economic consequences of continued progress in these areas could be enormous. Just as with previous technological revolutions, the people and countries who make decisions about how these systems operate and what values they reflect - including their approach to safety - will have huge influence over our lives.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIf this is to benefit the UK we must be an \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e maker, not just an \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e taker: \u003cstrong\u003ewe need companies at the frontier that will be our UK national champions.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe have all the raw ingredients to make this possible. \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e research and product development is a UK strength rooted in world-class engineering talent coming out of our excellent universities and local \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e winners such as DeepMind and Wayve. Our position between the US and Europe, and convenient time-zone, make the UK an ideal place for international founders to collaborate.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"#lay-the-foundations\"\u003eSection 1\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"#changes-lives\"\u003eSection 2\u003c/a\u003e of this Action Plan above are critical to building on this. Section 1 covered the policy and infrastructure needed for the growth of the domestic \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e sector. Section 2 covered the policies needed for widespread \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e adoption - a necessary condition for a world-leading \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e application ecosystem.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe should assume that most advanced economies will soon be doing much of the above. If we aspire to be one of the biggest winners from \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e and drive national renewal, we need to go further.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eGiven the lead the current frontier firms enjoy, we cannot expect the market to solely underwrite a new challenger, especially in the next 2 to 3 years. But government holds critical levers for the next stage of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e development. Generating national champions will require a more activist approach and something more akin to Japan’s MITI or Singapore’s Economic Development Board in the 1960s, not the “invisible hand”.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe government must maximise its ambition and ensure the UK has national champions at the frontier of economically and strategically important capabilities. This means government needs to:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eEnsure that research and development of frontier \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e capabilities takes place in the UK - both in the current foundation model paradigm and in emerging spaces such as \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e for science, robotics, and “embodied \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e”.\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eEnsure that the UK maximises both its economic upside from and influence on these capabilities as they advance.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003eAchieving this will require bold, concerted and coherent action, using all the levers of the state to make the UK the best place in the world to build and scale frontier \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e companies. While I don’t want to understate how difficult this will be, I am confident that with the right focus and backing, the UK can do this.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eTo this end, the government should:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e50. \u003cstrong\u003eCreate a new unit, UK Sovereign \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e, with the power to partner with the private sector to deliver the clear mandate of maximising the UK’s stake in frontier \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003ePublic-private collaboration will be at the heart of this unit. It will support the private and academic sectors in doing what they do best, with the ability to collaborate internationally, create joint ventures, as well as invest in, incubate and spin out \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e companies - refining its strategy and approach as the technology matures.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eTo achieve this, the unit must develop a clear position on which areas of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e research are strategically important for the future of the technology and make concentrated bets in these areas. This could involve supporting entrepreneurs to create new companies, backing startups to scale or partnering with existing \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e companies that are already at the frontier to maximise the UK’s upside however the technology develops.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWith a clear and powerful mandate the unit will play a critical coordinating role, able to remove barriers and make deals to maximise the UK’s chance of growing globally competitive national champions. It will need to be able to draw on the resources of government to act quickly and decisively. If it is to succeed, it will require support from other government organisations. Especially important will be Innovate UK, which should make \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e a top priority and support the unit through the funding it provides to promising start-ups.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eEarly tolerance for scientific and technical risk can be hugely valuable. For example, the unit or its public sector partners might join funding rounds or provide advanced market commitments to credible and ambitious startups in emerging fields of \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e. \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e for science is an area with the potential to be particularly important because of its economic value and security implications; the UK’s existing talent strengths; and the particularly high value of the state’s assets in this space. \u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe use of these non-financial assets, alongside capital and procurement, will be critical to the unit’s offer. \u003cstrong\u003eUK Sovereign \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e should lead the delivery of a government offer to new and existing frontier \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e companies that includes:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eDirect investment into companies, including promising start-ups as well as joint ventures with other commercial partners.\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eDelivering appropriate sites for compute in the UK, including through \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e Growth Zones, and international partnerships to guarantee compute access from appropriate allies.\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003ePackaging and providing responsible access to the most valuable UK-owned data sets and relevant research.\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eSupporting UK-based \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e organisations working on national priority projects to bring in overseas talent and headhunting promising founders or CEOs (and their teams) by convincing them to relocate to the UK.\u003c/li\u003e\n  \u003cli\u003eFacilitating deep collaboration with the national security community.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn exchange, UK Sovereign \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e should ensure economic upside from, and influence on, governance of frontier \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e for the UK.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e may well be the most important technology of our time. Now is the moment to act boldly and with vision so that the UK helps to shape \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e’s course and our citizens’ share in its upside.\u003c/p\u003e"

Government should also have the self-confidence and ambition to set an example for the rest of the economy. This will require a novel approach involving close collaboration with industry to ensure the whole of society can benefit from the opportunities offered by \u003cabbr title=\"artificial intelligence\"\u003eAI\u003c/abbr\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eBusiness-as-usual is not an option. Instead, government will need to be prepared to absorb some risk in the context of uncertainty. \u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis will require a whole of government commitment, with senior and visible leadership and a relentless focus on driving progress.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis is no small task.         <div class="govspeak"><p><abbr title="artificial intelligence">AI</abbr> Opportunities Action Plan</p>

<p>Presented to Parliament by the Secretary of State Science, Innovation and Technology by Command of His Majesty.</p>

<p>CP1241</p>
